posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked: Hi CD , We have 4 Cancoders for our swerve modules but I’m not sure what is the best way to power them. We’ve both MPM and VRM . We use VRM to power our radio. We also have a Raspberry Pi to power. Our initial config was PDH >MPM>| VRM & Cancoders & Raspberry Pi(5V additional regulator). | Would powering VRM directly from PDH and connecting Cancoders to VRM 12V 0.5A port be better or is our initial config better?

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
We ran them from the vrm last year and are running them from the PDH this year.

That change was because we didn’t need the VRM for anything else this year and had more than enough connectivity on the PDH .

I would wire whatever way is consistent and makes for clean wiring out of the way. The last thing you want is to lose power to these guys and be unable to drive.

posts.name: Chris_Elston
posts.cooked:
We run the mini board. It connects to one spot on the PDH , then you can install alot smaller fuses for stuff like Cancoder here:

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 35

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked: Currently we are using this MPM but as using more modules mean more points of failures, I’m considering whether to remove it.

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked: You need a VRM because you should want stable power to those devices. You can power all 4 from the 5V 500mA rail.

I believe it takes 12V. It’s rated for 6-16V so unless you’re running an absolutely ridiculous setup that backfeeds well over 6 volts into your battery, running it unregulated from the MPM shouldn’t be an issue.

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked:
Sure, that’s one option. I don’t deem it a good one though because I like to watch our robot compete and enjoy the show.

Knowing our cancoders have stable power, those devices are far less likely to cause us issues in a match.

Why take the chance on the raw battery power to your encoders that can plunge down to the 7V-ish levels repeatedly throughout a 150 second match?

The VRM gives you the best chance to compete at the highest level.

We chose the 5V rail for power because the 12V rail on the VRM was committed to then the OpenMesh radio. And I did not need to add a second VRM to the electrical plant.

That was us two years ago.

Now we use the CRTE Mag Encoders for steer angle position fed directly into the SparkMAX. We also earn the bonus of minimizing our CAN traffic.

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked:
mtuckerFRC4381:

We chose the 5V rail for power because the 12V rail on the VRM was committed to then the OpenMesh radio.

I believe only 12v 2A port is dedicated for radio. If I am not mistaken 500ma port doesn’t have that limitation.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
The minimum voltage for the CANcoder is 6V, so I don’t see why you’d consider 5V to be OK:

We run them off an MPM, which is powered from unregulated power from the PDH with no problems.

You can also power them from a Kraken PowerPole Adapter Board , which again just feeds it unregulated battery power.

posts.name: Thomas Heredia
posts.cooked:
The SRX Mag uses 5v.

But the power poles from wcp and refire are good options. We have a custom “Beancoder” housing that houses 2 microfit 2x2 connectors that we crimped into the sl 1x4 on the refire connector to power the cancoders+signal.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
BABER:

We use VRM to power our radio. We also have a Raspberry Pi to power. Our initial config was PDH >MPM>| VRM & Cancoders & Raspberry Pi(5V additional regulator). |

I don’t believe that R617 allows connecting a VRM that is powering the radio to an MPM.

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked: I was looking for raspberry wiring on CD and found this diagram. I should have checked manual. I didn’t see the part to connect radio to pdh in the linked post as I searched on google and clicked on the picture.
